Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Finite-Absorption-Bandwidth Materials for Cost-Effective Multijunction Photovoltaics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:
Nontechnical: Commercial solar cells that absorb visible light are reaching their theoretical and practical efficiency limits. An ideal strategy for improving their performance would be a new material that could simply be "stuck on top" of a current high-performing commercial cell, allowing it to harvest the invisible infrared radiation emitted by the sun. This project seeks to build a new class of flexible materials that only absorb in the infrared while transmitting visible light by using semiconductor particles with optical properties that depend on their nano- and micro-scale structures. Specifically, the goal is to make photonic crystals (structures in which certain frequency ranges of light cannot propagate) in strongly absorbing colloidal quantum dot films, to be used in color-tuned and transparent solar cells. The project has the potential to address broad societal goals in the development of more efficient renewable energy technologies, as alternatives to polluting and unsustainable fossil fuels, by developing lightweight, inexpensive, and flexible solar energy harvesting materials. Additionally, these materials could be ideal platforms for transparent and building-integrated solar cells. The project seeks to address fundamental questions on the role of different length scales in nanostructured materials, and how the interplay between them determines optical and electronic materials properties. Research activities will be integrated with a comprehensive education and outreach plan designed to introduce elementary school students, undergraduates, and graduate students to the fields of nanotechnology and sustainable engineering.

Technical: The objective of this study is to build new inorganic nanomaterials with finite absorption bandwidths that will be used to improve the efficiency of transparent and multi-junction solar cells. The project will take an innovative approach for making flexible nanoparticle films with spectrally-tailored absorption and transmission spectra based on novel realizations of photonic bandgaps in strongly absorbing colloidal-quantum-dot-based thin-film materials. Methods to be employed include computational simulations, chemical syntheses, solution-processed device fabrication, and electrical and optical device characterization. If successful, the research work will result in a new method for improving the efficiency of current solar cell technology by introducing a new class of active optoelectronic materials that absorb only in the infrared. These flexible photovoltaic materials could increase the efficiency of current commercial solar cell technology in a cost-effective way: the top infrared cells will transmit visible light to the bottom standard visible cells, achieving current-matching in a multi-junction structure without re-engineering current high-performing solar cell technology. This project also aims to answer open questions involving the interactions between nano-physical phenomena, how to achieve self-assembly and optical engineering on multiple length scales, and how artificial photonic band structures can be maintained in strongly absorbing media. The novel materials developed in this project have the potential to be used in a number of new technologies, including multi-junction solar cells, transparent photovoltaics, and other photonic and optoelectronic devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Spectral selectivity,” meaning the ability of materials to selectively absorb and emit some colors of light and not others, is an important property for many device applications, including in solar cells, light sensors, and communication technology. The research supported by this grant, “EAGER: Finite-Absorption-Bandwidth Materials for Cost-Effective Multijunction Photovoltaics,” had the goal of demonstrating a new method for achieving spectral selectivity in common absorptive materials: altering their physical structures in a way that caused them to selectively transmit and absorb certain colors of light.

 

In the course of the research, a new method for calculating the interactions between light and matter in specific structured materials was developed.  The method allows for quick and efficient calculations of the color profile of a material when its structure is changed, for example, by introducing a periodic set of voids in the material.  Although this had been done previously for materials that don’t absorb light, a major outcome of this project was calculating what happens in this situation when a material does absorb light. It turns out that most of the material behavior is retained in this case, except that the light-matter interactions can be even stronger at certain specific colors – this is what allows physical structuring of absorbing materials to potentially be used to control which colors of light they interact with.

 

Using the calculation method, specific materials composed of semiconductor particles with sizes on the nanometer scale were designed, made, and tested. These materials had weaker absorption of bluer colors and stronger absorption of redder colors, which is the opposite of how they behave when physical structuring is not used. This outcome could be used to build new types of solar cells that more efficiently absorb colors of sunlight that are not usually absorbed in a solar cell.  This, in turn, could enable higher power output and drive down the cost of solar energy.    

 

Additionally, new methods for making flexible metallic materials were developed during the course of the research project. A spray-painting setup was built and used to deposit thin layers of silver wires with sizes on the nanometer scale.  These materials were both transparent and conducted electricity as well as the typical materials used in solar cells without having to be heated to damaging high temperatures. This outcome could potentially allow bendable solar cells and sensors to be deposited on any surface.

 

Outcomes of this project include both advancing knowledge in the field of how useful materials interact with light, and enabling new technology with the potential to improve broad societal outcomes related to energy generation and environmental sensing. Flexible, efficient, clean, and inexpensive renewable energy technology enabled by this project could raise standards of living in developing world; improve global health outcomes by mitigating the effects of pollution/global warming; and improve environmental conditions by reducing pollution, drilling and other negative effects of fossil energy sources.

 

Eight students were partially trained by this project, including four PhD students, two masters students, and two undergraduates. This project also provided exposure to science and technology for young people and members of the public.  The members the PI’s research group involved in this project served as mentors with the STEM Achievement in Baltimore Elementary Schools (SABES) program through the Center for Educational Outreach at Johns Hopkins University. SABES is a partnership between Johns Hopkins and the Baltimore City Public Schools with the goal of boosting STEM achievement and interest in the local community. Research group members serve as mentors for a 3rd grade classroom at Robert W. Coleman Elementary School in Baltimore. Two team members visited the classroom once per week to help teach the SABES curriculum and mentor students in carrying out a final capstone engineering project. In order to engage broader members of the public, the PI gave a talk at the first ever “Pint of Science” event held in the U.S. Pint of Science is a non-profit organization that brings scientists to local bars or cafés to discuss their latest research findings in an informal atmosphere with anyone from the community who is interested. The discussed the results of the research project and the future of solar energy.
